case_vignette: A 21-year-old male presents for evaluation of a painful rash on his right index finger. He reports a tingling sensation prior to the eruption of red small spots that became more yellow and pus filled. He denies any trauma or topical products applied to the area. He has a history of cold sores on the lips. Physical examination reveals multiple clustered painful, white-yellow vesicles on the right index finger on erythematous pink base.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a painful rash on my right index finger that started with a tingling feeling and then turned into small red spots that got more yellow and pus-filled.
Is this rash accompanied by fever or other joint pain?
No, I don't have a fever or joint pain.
What is your age and sex?
I am a 21-year-old male.
Have you recently injured or cut your finger?
No, I haven't injured or cut my finger.
Is this rash present for more than a week?
You didn't provide me with information about how long the rash has been present, so I can't answer that.

I apologize for that mistake. The rash has been present for how long?

**Final Diagnosis:** Pustular Psoriasis (if rash has been present for more than a week and no injury or cut to the finger)
